content.description: Two brands of golf cart batteries, R and S, were tested to investigate whether there is a difference between the proportions of fully charged batteries that could power a golf cart for at least thirty miles. A random sample of <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> brand R batteries was selected and a random sample of <math alttext="50" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> brand S batteries was selected. Batteries were randomly assigned to one of <math alttext="100" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> different golf carts. Each cart was driven until the battery failed. Of the carts with brand R batteries, <math alttext="40" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>40</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> traveled over thirty miles, and of the carts with brand S batteries, <math alttext="35" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>35</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> traveled over thirty miles.
content.question: Which of the following is a <math alttext="95" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>95</mn></mrow></mstyle></math> percent confidence interval for the difference in the proportions of fully charged batteries that can power a golf cart for at least thirty miles for the two brands?

choices.label: <math alttext="open parenthesis, 0.8 minus 0.7, close parenthesis, plus or minus 1.645 times the square root of the fraction 0.8 times 0.2, over 50, end fraction, times the fraction 0.7 times 0.3, over 50, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>1.645</mn><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mo>)</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.7</mn><mo>)</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="open parenthesis, 0.8 minus 0.7, close parenthesis, plus or minus 1.645 times the square root of the fraction 0.8 times 0.2, over 50, end fraction, minus the fraction 0.7 times 0.3, over 50, end root" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mo>−</mo><mn>0.7</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>±</mo><mn>1.645</mn><msqrt><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.8</mn><mo>)</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mfrac><mo>−</mo><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.7</mn><mo>)</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>0.3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>50</mn></mrow></mfrac></mrow></mrow></msqrt></mrow></mstyle></math>

topic.text: 6.8: Confidence Intervals for the Difference of Two Proportions

skill.text: Skill 3.D: Construct a confidence interval, provided conditions for inference are met.
